articles.headline: Biden Names Lina Khan, a Big-Tech Critic, as F.T.C. Chair
articles.snippet: Ms. Khan, who first attracted notice as a critic of Amazon, was confirmed by the Senate as a commissioner on the agency on Tuesday.
articles.abstract: Ms. Khan, who first attracted notice as a critic of Amazon, was confirmed by the Senate as a commissioner on the agency on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden named Lina Khan, a prominent critic of Big Tech, as the chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission, the White House said on Tuesday, a signal that the agency is likely to crack down further on the industry’s giants.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Once, Superpower Summits Were About Nukes. Now, It’s Cyberweapons.
articles.snippet: But with the ease of denying responsibility and the wide range of possible attackers, the traditional deterrents of the nuclear age no longer work.
articles.abstract: But with the ease of denying responsibility and the wide range of possible attackers, the traditional deterrents of the nuclear age no longer work.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — For 70 years, meetings between American presidents and Soviet or Russian leaders were dominated by one looming threat: the vast nuclear arsenals that the two nations started amassing in the 1940s, as instruments of intimidation and, if deterrence failed, mutual annihilation.

articles.headline: U.S. Nears 600,000 Virus Deaths Despite Progress From Vaccines
articles.snippet: Daily deaths have dropped considerably since their January peak, with about 44 percent of the population now fully vaccinated.
articles.abstract: Daily deaths have dropped considerably since their January peak, with about 44 percent of the population now fully vaccinated.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a number that once seemed unimaginable.
articles.byline: By Dan Levin and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: The U.S. Averted One Housing Crisis, but Another Is in the Wings
articles.snippet: A moratorium on evictions did little to address the bigger problem: The country is running out of affordable places for people to live.
articles.abstract: A moratorium on evictions did little to address the bigger problem: The country is running out of affordable places for people to live.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States averted the most dire predictions about what the pandemic would do to the housing market. An eviction wave never materialized. The share of people behind on mortgages, after falling steadily for months, recently hit its prepandemic level.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Buyers of Amazon Devices Are Guinea Pigs. That’s a Problem.
articles.snippet: Amazon’s experimental approach to product design can hurt your wallet and the environment. Why does it need our help to figure out what it’s doing?
articles.abstract: Amazon’s experimental approach to product design can hurt your wallet and the environment. Why does it need our help to figure out what it’s doing?
articles.lead_paragraph: About four years ago, Paul Hollowell found out that Amazon was making a gadget he desperately wanted: a camera whose sole purpose was to photograph his clothes.

articles.headline: Why American Women Everywhere Are Delaying Motherhood
articles.snippet: The birthrate is falling for American women in their 20s, especially in places where the local economy is booming.
articles.abstract: The birthrate is falling for American women in their 20s, especially in places where the local economy is booming.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Luz Portillo, the oldest daughter of Mexican immigrants, has many plans. She is studying to be a skin care expert. She has also applied to nursing school. She works full time, too — as a nurse’s aide and doing eyelash extensions, a business she would like to grow.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise, Claire Cain Miller, Quoctrung Bui and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Federal Reserve Officials Project Rate Increases in 2023
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve left rates near zero, but it said it would tiptoe closer to reducing its mass bond purchases, among other optimistic tweaks.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve left rates near zero, but it said it would tiptoe closer to reducing its mass bond purchases, among other optimistic tweaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials signaled on Wednesday that they expected to raise interest rates from rock bottom sooner than they had previously forecast and that they were taking baby steps toward reducing their vast bond purchases — tweaks that, together, demonstrated their increasing confidence that the economy would rebound robustly from the pandemic.

articles.headline: Taiwan Wants German Vaccines. China May Be Standing in Its Way.
articles.snippet: The two sides have traded accusations about whether political motivations are keeping the Taiwanese people from receiving immunizations amid the island’s first major Covid-19 outbreak.
articles.abstract: The two sides have traded accusations about whether political motivations are keeping the Taiwanese people from receiving immunizations amid the island’s first major Covid-19 outbreak.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — This is the age of “vaccine diplomacy.” It is also the era of its bitter, mudslinging opposite.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong and Christopher F. Schuetze
